>>>>> "S" == S Alexander Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    S> Its nice that they defined a protocol for these things on top
    S> of SOAP, but is there any reason to believe that if they had
    S> put this design effort into doing it on top of HTTP/SMTP (and
    S> perhaps RESTfully), we would not have these services without
    S> the SOAP horror?

Maybe. Or would we have ended with a lot of HTTP horror? I don't
know. The world's data doesn't neatly fit in name/value pairs.


    S> ...
    S> RESTful and transactional without all of SOAP's plumbing.

    S> ...
    S> Message is processed (and in order) only if all external-bodies
    S> are present.

    S> Note: This protocol nests.  The commit message may itself have
    S> a transaction: yes header in which case it waits until someone
    S> commits the commmit.

This is so wrong, that I must assume you have not worked on enterprise
level applications. I hardly know how to correct you, but I'll try:

1. What if an entity I invoke, invokes other entities, and what if
   they have transactions of their own? Are they in the same
   transaction? A new transaction? Do they nest?

2. What if an entity I invoke also sends messages? Are they in the
   transaction as well? In what order?

3. If the client goes down, is the transaction committed? Rolled back?

4. Doing two or three phase commit at the client is really innovative
   I assume... What do we need transaction managers for??


    >> 5. Priorization.

    S> I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you don't want it
    S> because it violates the End-To-End principle.

Absolutely not! If I want to have certain orders served at higher
priority, why should software prevent me? If I want paying customers
to serve at a higher priority at some site, why not?


    S> PS The above protocols are entirely strawmen made to make a
    S> point and set us on the road to industrial stength variants.
    S> Please be gentle.

Maybe I sounded a bit harsh, not my intention really. If you have not
worked with transaction managers and the Corba/MTS (COM+) stuff, you
might not have a real idea what those can do for you and what problems
they try to solve.

My intention is not to defend what they are doing, or to deny there
might be better ways to solve it. But the issues they try to solve are
real, and they bring in a lot of value.
